Your reason for this claim is that stenographers' work can be put into an app. While it is true that technology has advanced significantly and there are various transcription software available, I disagree with your reasoning that court stenographers are not necessary solely based on the development of these apps.

Firstly, court stenographers serve a crucial role in the legal system by providing real-time transcription services during court proceedings. These professionals possess the necessary skills and training to accurately transcribe spoken words into text. While transcription apps can provide automated transcriptions, they may not always capture the nuances, multiple speakers, or specialized legal terminology with the same level of accuracy as a trained stenographer. They may also struggle in environments with background noise or technical issues.

Secondly, court stenographers not only transcribe proceedings but also provide additional support services such as marking exhibits, maintaining records, and editing transcripts. These tasks require human judgment, understanding of legal processes, and the ability to prioritize information effectively. While apps may assist in the transcription process, they often cannot fulfill these additional responsibilities.

Furthermore, court stenographers also play a crucial role in maintaining the integrity of the legal process. They can provide immediate clarification or correction of the transcript when necessary, ensuring an accurate record of the proceedings. Stenographers are also trained to maintain confidentiality and impartiality during sensitive legal discussions, which may be challenging for an app to embody.

In conclusion, while technology has advanced and transcription apps have been developed, I believe court stenographers are necessary in the legal system. Their skills, expertise, and ability to accurately transcribe and provide additional support services outweigh the limitations of automated transcription apps. Court stenographers contribute to the accuracy, efficiency, and integrity of the legal process and provide a human element that cannot be replicated by technology alone. Therefore, I disagree with your reasoning that "Court stenographers are not necessary" based solely on the availability of transcription apps.

While transcription apps have indeed improved in accuracy and efficiency, they still have certain limitations that prevent them from fully replacing court stenographers. First, although transcription apps are designed to handle different speakers and specialized legal terminology, there can still be instances where they struggle to accurately transcribe certain accents, speech patterns, or complex legal jargon. Court stenographers, with their training and experience, can navigate these challenges more effectively.

Second, automated transcription apps may lack the ability to make real-time clarifications or corrections during court proceedings. Stenographers can actively participate in the legal process by ensuring the accuracy of the transcript, addressing any errors, and providing immediate clarification when needed. This interactive and adaptable nature of court stenographers cannot be replicated solely by an app.

Furthermore, the importance of the human element and contextual understanding that court stenographers bring to the legal system cannot be overlooked. They possess the ability to interpret tone, differentiate between homophones, and understand contextual nuances that automated apps may struggle with. These skills contribute to the accuracy and reliability of the transcription, ensuring an authentic record of the proceedings.

In conclusion, while transcription apps have improved and offer certain benefits, they still have limitations in accurately capturing all aspects of court proceedings. The expertise, adaptability, and human judgment that court stenographers bring to the legal system cannot be fully replaced by technology alone. Therefore, I maintain my stance that court stenographers are necessary in the legal process, even considering the development of transcription apps.
